security_audit.summary: This is a legitimate project management tool with no security risks. All scripts are read-only analysis tools that parse YAML files and generate reports. No network calls, file system access beyond local files, or code execution capabilities detected.

content.user_title: Track Software Features with YAML-Based Requirements Management
content.value_statement: Software projects need structured requirement tracking beyond simple todo lists. This skill provides waterfall-style feature management with requirements, test cases, and progress tracking in a persistent YAML format.
actual_capabilities: Create and manage features.yml files with structured requirements
Track feature phases from Requirements to Complete
Link test cases to requirements with passing/failing status
Generate reports on work remaining, issues, and feature status
Validate phase transitions and requirement completeness
limitations: Requires features.yml file to exist for proactive usage
Waterfall methodology may not suit all projects
No integration with external project management tools
Manual status updates required during development

use_cases.title: Track implementation progress
use_cases.description: Manage feature requirements and mark them complete as you implement functionality, with linked test cases for verification.

use_cases.title: Monitor feature development
use_cases.description: Get overview of all features, their phases, progress, and failing tests to track project status.

use_cases.title: Manage test coverage
use_cases.description: Link test cases to requirements and track which tests are passing or failing for each feature.

prompt_templates.title: Create new feature
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a features.yml file for implementing user authentication with requirements for login, logout, and password reset functionality.

prompt_templates.title: Update feature status
prompt_templates.prompt: Update the user authentication feature in features.yml to mark the login requirement as Complete and add a test case for it.

prompt_templates.title: View work remaining
prompt_templates.prompt: Show me all incomplete requirements across all features in features.yml, filtered to Implementation phase.

prompt_templates.title: Check feature status
prompt_templates.prompt: Generate a markdown report of all features showing their phases, progress, test status, and any validation errors.

output_examples.input: Show the status of all features

best_practices: Use EARS syntax for requirements: 'When X, the system SHALL Y'
Update status immediately after completing work to keep file in sync
Document design decisions in the decisions field before implementation
Link every requirement to at least one test case for traceability
anti_patterns: Creating features.yml after starting implementation instead of planning first
Leaving requirements in Not-Started status when actively working on them
Forgetting to bump version when adding or modifying requirements
Not documenting known issues that could affect other developers

faq.question: When should I use this skill versus TodoWrite?
faq.answer: Use TodoWrite for immediate session tasks and features.yml for persistent project requirements that span multiple sessions.

faq.question: What happens if features.yml doesn't exist?
faq.answer: The skill will not activate proactively. You must manually create features.yml or request the skill to create one.

faq.question: Can I integrate this with my existing project management tool?
faq.answer: The skill works independently with YAML files. You can manually sync data to other tools as needed.

faq.question: How do I handle requirement changes after implementation starts?
faq.answer: Document the change rationale, update the requirement, increment version, and add a changelog entry under the appropriate section.

faq.question: What if my project uses agile instead of waterfall?
faq.answer: Adapt the phases to your workflow. The tool is flexible - use phases that match your development process.

faq.question: How do I track bugs versus requirements?
faq.answer: Add bugs to the known-issues field. Requirements represent planned features while known-issues track defects.
